title-group.article-title: Influence of Gas Turbine Cycle Parameters on Regenerator Geometry

permissions.copyright-statement: Â© Society of Automotive Engineers, Inc., 1970

abstract.p: Two nondimensional parameters are used to describe relative sizes of regenerative heat exchangers, regardless of type or surface characteristics. These are: ${\phi _S}\,\alpha \,\frac{{Total\,heat\,transfer\,surface}}{{Net\,engine\,power\,output}}$ and ${\phi _A}\,\alpha \,\frac{{Total\,heat\,transfer\,matrix\,face\,area}}{{Net\,engine\,power\,output}}$ They are related to gas turbine cycle factors to demonstrate that, for fixed bsfc goals, heat exchanger matrix sizes are very sensitive to turbine inlet temperature, pressure ratio, and flow path efficiency. Methods for optimizing engine cycles to minimize the sizing factors are described. A general trend toward higher pressure ratios in future recuperative gas turbines is indicated.

ref.mixed-citation: H. J. Wood, "Polytropic Technique for Gas Turbine Performance Prediction and Evaluation." SAE Transactions, Vol. 75 (1967), paper 660161.
W. M. Kays and A. L. London, "Compact Heat Ex- changers." New York: McGraw-Hill, 1964.

H. H. Osborn, R. K. Sharp, R. J. H. Liljelund, R. Erich- horn, and P. C. Wolf, "Performance and Potential of Perforated Plates as a Heat Transfer Surface." Paper No. 68-GT-33 presented at ASME Gas Turbine Conference and Products Show, Washington, D. C., 1968.
